1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1900
Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina, Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? Salt Lake City, Utah
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About every two weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, salt, sugar, baking powder, salt, sugar, rolled oats, dried fruits, soda, yeast.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Red Star
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs per month
That was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.75
How much did you use graham flour? 50 lbs
Whole wheat flour? Yes
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 12 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.35
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a hand mill

14. Fuel

That fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? At home, from friends, and local stores.

Has there been any change in the type of fuel used? Coal used in our furnace since about 1912.

Now we use fuel oil in our kitchen stove and are looking forward to an electric range this summer as we have the budget.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and in it the States or country, if any, where you lived at the time.

Breakfast - Oatmeal porridge

Porched eggs & yea, tapioca pudding, fried pork, yea.

Dinner - Beefsteak, fried bread, yea.

Supper - Bread, fruit or syrup, yea, cake

18. What was served for Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

We used to spend Christmas at my husband's station and entertain at New Year.

Menu - Roast turkey, canned corn, creamed potatoes, pickles, yams, pudding.

Those present - Mrs. Mrs. Airdman & children.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on or near local produce? Give details.
17. Give a typical day's menu (family) for the earliest settlers.

Breakfast - Oatmeal porridge

Practiced eggs & tea

Dinner - Beefsteak, fried pork, tapioca pudding, bread, yea.

Supper - Bread, fruit or apple pie, cake

18. What year did you arrive in Oregon?

We used to spend Christmas at my husband's parents' in eastern Oregon.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level? Living on oats or other locally produced foods? Give details.

Yes.
Our threshing gangs were about 16 men
and it meant separating as many as one
dozen peels before they came off lots of
cake and biscuits every day with the
combine we need only one man to haul
grain to our granaries so harvest and
threshing are not much different to
ordinary days on our farms.

You still want home-canned vegetables

a great deal

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries
and securing foods in your early life. (Please give as much detail as
possible.) (Please see page 15 for more details.) (This book of
memories, "Teaching our sons," is needed)

You had much trouble from flour
milled from green wheat. Our bread
would flatten out instead of rising up.
We overcome this by mixing some
Robin Hood flour with our locally
milled flour. We were forced to buy in
larger quantities on account of the
distance from our stores. We used to
sell eggs for 84¢ a dozen but we could
buy a yard of print with the 8¢ pair of fine shoes
(?)
Our thrashing gangs were about to move
and it meant gathering as many as one
deep piers before they could carry all the lots of
corn and beans, and the day with the
confining we need only one man to haul
grain to our granaries so prevalent and
thrashing an not much different to
ordinary days on our farms.

We still want home-canned vegetables

a quiet deal
